speaker: Mr Broadbenti Am Not Sure About Pyramid Hill, But 1 Know About The Area That 1 Live
theText: MC686 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 May 1996 greater honour than to represent a seat such as McMillan. I am humbled to be able to represent the seat I have lived in for the whole of my life and to begin to address issues such as dairy industry issues in regard to the bill that we are discussing today. There are some things that I want to mention about the dairy industry. One is that it has never stopped training young people. At the McMillan VCAH Campus outside Warragul there is a very special program, at the moment, which takes on people as apprentices in the dairy industry. I do not think we have done enough training; I do not think you can ever do enough training in any industry that you are in. In our area, the dairy industry is taking an active part and actually plays a role in what is happening with these young people, who are going onto dairy farms and learning the processes. The former government went wrong when it never did a family impact statement to determine what was happening to people in rural communities, or a family impact statement on the effects of bills that go before this House. Before the election we said to the people of Australia, 'When we introduce a bill, whatever that bill is, we are going to look at the impact that it will have on families, on family farms, on family businesses, and on families who work in cities or in country areas.' I hope that family impact statements will come before this Main Committee and before the parliament because if we cannot decide how legislation affects the family unit, how it affects individuals, then we are failing the Australian community. After spending the next three years in this parliament I do not want to look back on my time in the parliament and say, 'Like the previous government, we failed to look at the impact of legislation on families.' We have to do everything in this House we possibly can to uphold the family unit and we have to do everything we can to maintain our determination to look after the family unit. We. want to encourage the family farm and encourage the family businesses that create the wealth. They are the wealth creators in our electorates. I remember the training levy that has now fallen in a hole. I was in the parliament when that was introduced and I said then, 'This will not be a goer for the Australian community.' We were howled down at the time but it has been proved that it is not a goer for the Australian community. Commonsense is coming finally to our family farms and to our communities. Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for giving me the opportunity to address these amendments to the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill. I look forward to supporting the dairy farmers in my electorate of McMillan. They playa major role in the provision of wealth in the whole of the electorate. They will continue to play that role as long as we as a parliament are prepared to support them by getting out of their lives and letting them get on with what they do best. What they do best is work hard. They play hard too but they work hard and they produce very well . for this nation. Thank you very much. before you twice this morning, once in the other place and now here. These bills are going to reinforce some changes that were implemented last year. They had their genesis in the establishment of the GATT agreement and prior to that in the establishment of the milk levy under the so-called Kerin plan. I was not involved in the federal parliament then but I was certainly involved in my local community and it has a fairly extensive dairy industry. Certainly it is not as large as exists in the electorates of my Victorian colleagues sitting in front of me but still it is a very important rural industry in my electorate.
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Vaile Clyne) 01.49 A.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I have had the honour of appearingWednesday, 8 May 1996 MAINCOMMIITEE MC687 As a result of representing the dairy industry in my electorate I have always had contact with key people in the New South Wales section of the dairy industry. Going back all those years to the start of the Kerin plan, I point out that that plan was precipitated by a bit of tension between the New South Wales and Victorian dairy industries. circumstances under which the industry could work and prosper. Certainly it has prospered since then. Then we had the advent of the GAIT agreement and the World Trade Organisation, which Australia is signatory to. I will still maintain my limited support of that, as I have stated on many occasions in this place in the last three years. I maintain that Australia and the government of the day were very rash in their moves to lead the world as far as tariff reduction was concerned. There is evidence of that in some of the available figures concerning what is happening in the United States with the support of their dairy industry and export markets, compared with ours, and what I call, to a certain extent, the corrupt attitude of a lot of the agricultural trading nations of the world. There does not seem to be the amount of bona fides and the commitment to these tariff reductions in other countries that there has been in Australia. A lot of people would argue that there have been benefits. Sure, I think we have to go down that path. But as far as I am concerned-and I am only a lay person in these things-I do not believe it has been equitably done. We have been reducing our tariffs at a greater rate than some of the other participants in that agreement. We are never going to reach the same level because it is a percentage reduction each year, not a percentage of or getting down to a percentage tariff. That makes it doubly difficult. It makes it extremely difficult for people in our rural industries to compete in the world market place, particularly-as the member for McMillan( Mr Broadbent) so rightly pointed out-as previous governments have paid scant regard to the input costs of industry in Australia, particularly rural industries. Our rural industries have a factor that other industries do not have to deal with and that is the climate. They have been affected detrimentally in recent years by that. It is something that people in the rest of Australia sometimes have a great deal of difficulty coming to terms with. They ask: why should we, the taxpayers of Australia, be lending our support to people in those industries? But the taxpayers of Australia go to work in the morning and come home at night and at the end of the week their wages are transferred into their bank accounts, particularly in this city where there are more than 300,000 people. There are some very good people who work in this city. But a lot of the people who work in this city have not had the experience of what it takes to actually physically generate income; it is just there in the bank at the end of each week. People in Australia should have a greater understanding of what crises face people on the land from time to time and the difficulties that they face in producing a very important part of the wealth of this nation. We are-and for a long, long time into the future will always bea commodity trading nation. We should not lose sight of that fact. We need to be developing our manufacturing industries; we need to be developing our IT industries to compete and to work in the world marketplace. But just bear in mind that we are always going to be a major exporter of agricultural and mining products. They are going to form, for many years to come, the backbone of our economy.

theText: That is an understatement.

speaker: Mr Vaile
theText: Importantly, it was the industry that took action to create a set ofMC 688 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 8 May 1996 As a result of the implementation of the World Trade Organisation in the middle of last year, it became necessary for the then minister and the industry generally to address the mechanisms that were in place for the all milk levy. It was deemed prior to that date that the way they were implemented was actually illegal under GAIT. I questioned that at the time in a speech that I made in this very chamber about that issue. To be a member of that trading club we have got to play by those rules, whether we agree with them or not, and go down that path. The bills that we have before us today are about making the activities taking place in the industry better reflected in legislation. I would just like to make a comparison of the two support mechanisms, between us and the US. I acknowledge that it is a sensitive issue and that the minister is here, but it is important. This information update on the dairy industry is dated April 1996, so it is reasonably recent. In it there is a fair bit said about what is happening in the US as far as their dairy industry and their dairy export incentive program are concerned. In recent years, our market has been the subject of the wheat export enhancement program under a recent farm bill. The most recent farm bill is directing support mechanisms at our dairy industry Asian marketplace. The update says: The US announced on 1 April target destinations for sales of subsidised product under the DEIP program. Second-quarter allocations were generally unchanged, including 48,000t of SMP (lO,OOOt to Asia), 4,000t ofWMP.... SMP sales to Asia under the March quarter allocation totalled 7,119t at an average subsidy of US$4751t. The indicative fob price of around US$I,950/t was below Australian contractual prices during the ftrst quarter. Domestic production ftgures for the first two months of 1996 show a definite switching by producers from butterlSMP production to cheese production. Wholesale cheese for processing prices during March and April were at seasonally high levels, around US$3,OOO/t. Butter and SMP production were three per cent, and six per cent lower at llO,460t and 87,05Ot respectively. It goes on: Presidential approval was given in early April to the 1996-2000 US Fann Bill. The Bill legislates for a gradual phasing out of the dairy minimum price support program over a four-year period. The accompanying table indicates-this is very interesting-in Australian cents per litre terms, that the support being provided in the US in 1996 is 32.2 cents per litre, and that it is phasing down over four years at the end of 1999 to 30.8 cents. They have 30.8 Australian cents per litre support. It is a fair difference from what we have got that is being provided predominantly by the producers for their own industry to maintain their competitiveness on the world market. The document goes on: However, fanngate payments for manufacturing milk have generally been substantially above support levels in the 1990s. (Fanngate manufacturing milk prices in Australia in 1994-95 averaged 24 Aus. cents per litre.) The Bill fundsthat is the farm billthe export program Dairy Export Incentive Program through to 2002, up to Uruguay Round limits on subsidised volumes. The National Dairy Board will also be able to budget for export market development. So my view is that we have always moved ahead of the game in tariff reduction, in terms of subsidy reduction. We have wanted to be shining white knights leading the way in this area, whereas a lot of our trading .opposition is working to the absolute limits of the margin, and if it can fudge over the edge, it will. Wednesday, 8 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC689 It is incumbent upon this government-and I have made that abundantly clear to the minister at the table and also to the Minister for Trade( Mr Tim Fischer)-that we take a fairly hardnosed attitude in our trade negotiations when we are in those forums, talking about these things. It is incumbent upon this government to do everything that is humanly possible in the interests of our rural industries. I assure the House that that will certainly be the case. it may be done with a bit more empathy than it has been in recent years. I acknowledged earlier in my address-and it may have been before you were here-that the facilitator of the early plan in the restructuring of the dairy industry was the then minister. That is how the Kerin plan got its name. It was all about the industry helping the industry survive. The industry did not come to the government or to the taxpayers of Australia and say, 'We want you to subsidise our products so that we can compete. We want you to organise this marketplace. We want you to do this and to do that.' Mr Sawford interjectingMrV AILE--You stick to your wool. They worked through this, so this industry could become one the most successful primary industries in Australia today. Through that restructuring process, a lot of people and production units were lost to the industry. As with all major manufacturing primary production industries, that process had to take place and we have yet to see more such processes in other agricultural industries. In the dairy industry, the production units became bigger, more viable and more equitable as far as their equity ratios were concerned. Therefore, we have ended up with an industry committed to develop into a competitive industry in the international marketplace-and it will. When the bill to make the mechanisms GATT-legal came into this place last year-I am not sure when it was-it had the support of the coalition on the day. We wanted to make sure that we gave the support to the dairy industry that it deserves, because it has done the hard yards. Some of the other primary industries are yet to do them. The dairy industry has become very efficient in both production and manufacturing. MrV AILE--All we have to do now is to implement micro-economic refonn at the next stage in the process on the transportation side-on the wharves and so on-to keep faith with the dairy industry as a major export industry. As it is in place now, the mechanism sees a contribution coming from a couple of different sections of the industry. A manufacturer's levy of 4c a litre is collected and put into the market support fund. A market milk levy of 2c a litre from producers goes into the fund. The fund provides market support of 2.2c a litre to producers of market milk. Presumably this mechanism makes the thing GAIT-legal because we are dealing with the domestic situation, not a direct export enhancement situation. This strengthens the industry and makes it more competitive on the international market as far as exports are concerned. A lot of private players in this industry are making great strides as far as exports are concerned. One dairy factory in Taree is developing a new product and . selling labelled product, not just generic product, into Asia that is earning a lot of export dollars for Australia, and doing it extremely well.

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: And improved quality.MC690 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 May 1996 This is all about supporting the industry as a whole, but it stiII begs the question. In the US fann biII, by 1999 they are looking at 30.8c Australian per litre support in the US. Interestingly, one paragraph says: The Bill funds the export program (DEIP) through to 2002, up to Uruguay Round limits ... It says 'up to'. They are going to work to the margins all the way. They are going to make us earn every export dollar that our industry can. Because it is a major export earner, this industry in this country deserves every little bit of support from both sides of this House. It has certainly reconstructed itself without the absorption or the subsidy that a lot of other industries have had. The dairy industry would have loved to have had the hundreds of millions of dollars that were spent in reform on the waterfront-the Clayton's reform on the waterfront that did not really have any effect. The dairy industry would have loved that sort of public funding in its restructuring process. keep supporting this industry in these ways so we can facilitate what they are doing for themselves. More than that, we have to support this industry and our other major primary, manufacturing and mining industries in this country so they can get on with the job of microeconomic reform. Mr Deputy Speaker, this government will do that. Make no bones about it, the people of Australia need not be concerned as to whether this government.has the backbone to do it. It certainly does. Before my time expires, I go back to the comment by the member for McMiIlan that the dairy industry is one of those major training grounds for young people. There are some of the labour market programs that were put in place in recent years that are working within the dairy industry. They do train young people-there are dairying apprenticeships in the industry-and we do not want to see those young people lost to the industry. That raises the point that while it is good to train someone, it is not an apprenticeship that can take place in a matter of years. It takes quite a few years because it is not just about a job, it is about a lifestyle. The way it is done involves a great deal of commitment to the industry and what it is doing, and a love of rural industries. The next question that raises is about the intergenerational change of farms and how people afford the financial arrangements needed to do that. With the intergenerational change in a family farm, how does the retiring dairy farmer get out, when he wants to leave that production unit to his family, and still be able to live? My personal view is that the mechanisms that are in place now are not suitable and certainly need review. We have to look at all those issues if we expect to maintain viable rural industries in Australia. That goes not just for the dairy industry, but for all our rural industries. So it is very important that we look at the financial mechanisms to enable intergenerational transfer of some of our most important industries in Australia. I am supporting the two bills that are before the House this morning and the way that the government has moved in its support for the dairy industry. Some of the industry leaders come from my electorate, which has always produced a number of the major industry leaders in New South Wales. They have my full support and they certainly know where I stand on the dairy industry. All Australians should recognise that this industry has done the hard yards, predominantly by themselves financially, sorted it out and got themselves into one of the most

speaker: Mr Vaile
theText: It might be a disingenuous comment, but it is a factual one. We have got toWednesday, 8 May 1996 MAIN COMMITfEE MC691 efficient producing industries in Australia that is earning much needed export dollars for this nation. Energy( Mr Anderson), I am sure I speak for all private members in noting, with appreciation, the action of the minister in coming to the Main Committee to close the debate in reply. We hope that the ministerial drought in this chamber continues to be broken. reply-Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is the title you assume in this place as well as in the other, I understand. in this debate. There is obviously strong support across the political spectrum for Australia's dairy industry and a recognition that this debate is centred on some straightforward administrative amendments which in no way represent significant policy change and are a further tidying up-if I can use that sort of terminology-of the reinstrumentation of the old all-milk levy arrangements. They were, in my view, a very clever industry funded and industry driven set of export enhancement arrangements which played a significant part in boosting the export performance of the dairy industry. Over the last couple of decades, it has turned from being a rather parochial and inward looking industry with quite a few deep-rooted structural problems-very low levels of farm profitability, low levels of efficiency, and supplying essentially the domestic market-into one which is now aggressively outward looking and is really setting the pace in terms of export performance. The amendments bring us into line with our international obligations as a nation which is not only a signatory to the WTO but an originator and driver of the whole push for trade reform in the agricultural area. SoI do place on record my appreciation for the contributions made to this debate by people from both sides of politics. I would like to recap briefly on some of the remarks that have been made about the performance of the dairy industry. We can be genuinely proud of it. It is generally assumed now that we can wear the cap as the world's second most efficient dairy producer--only New Zealand is generally perceived to still have a bit of an edge on us. At the outer edges of our capacity-and I note that the member for Murray( Mrs Stone) is here-what you are seeing in the Goulburn Valley today would equal the world's best performance, really. The explosion in value adding, innovation and performance in every way in that area is something to behold. It is part and parcelinvestment is on the way in your part of the world-which we again welcome because that is part and parcel of whatSomebody from the wool industry said to me the other day, 'You know, we have to do in this . industry what the dairy industry did, and turn ourselves around.' That is what you would begin with. What we need to do-

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: No; they are all woollies in western Victoria. I will tell you something.MC692 MAIN COMMI'ITEE Wednesday, 8 May 1996 Minister. address your remarks through the chair? through you. The point ought to be made that the dairy industry has achieved much of what it has achieved through effective leadership. I have said publicly that I do have a concern that the wool industry could learn well from the model set before it, in as much as I note with some delight that the various sectors of the wool industry have recently begun to cooperate more and are not publicly criticising one another in the way that they had been in the past. The wool industry is one that, in my view, needs to engage in a greater degree of fermentation, if you like, of leadership from within its own ranks, and to push that leadership up and then support it, get behind it and make it all happen. I say that with the best will in the world, because I have some concerns that we need to do for the wool industry what the dairy industry successfully managed to achieve for itself in recent years. We have actually seen the dairy industry set a scorching pace in Asia. We hear a lot in this country about how our future lies in Asia and that is where the opportunities will be. Yet the reality is that, because we have been so reluctant to grapple with effective reform in this country, our market share in expanding Asian markets in many ways-and in a wide range of products-has been slipping. It has not been increasing, but slipping-an appalling indictment of economic, industrial relations and taxation policy under the regime that has in this country just been comprehensively booted out. In contrast-and in a moment I will come to some of the historical reasons that the dairy industry has been able to achieve a few things that others have not-dairy has seen its share of the lucrative Asian markets increase over recent years from an already impressive 29 per cent to 34 per cent last year. Currently, it has over one billion dollars worth of exports on an annualised basis. That is a performance of which the rest of the Australian community ought to be very proud; but, at the same time, we ought to be enormously challenged by it. It is in fact a model of what we all ought to be doing but cannot do. Look at the meat industry, where we are being pushed back out of Asia. Why? Largely because it is an industry based not on cooperation but on confrontation, particularly at the level of industrial relations. One reason that the dairy industry has made such great progress is that one of the great things that it had going for it-even though 20 years ago it was fragmented, small and rather inward-looking-was that it was built on a cooperative model. It was built on an understanding that there needed to be good linkages between all of the players: between the dairy farmers themselves and the cooperatives that they formed and the activities of the cooperatives, including those of an industrial relations nature. They were largely decentralised, too, out in rural Australia, and sometimes I suspect it was a little difficult for the agitators and others who would have made trouble to get out there and organise. As a result of its cooperative approach, the dairy industry has made tremendous progress. You will be only too well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker-representing, as you do, a rural region in this country-that very many farm families enjoy extraordinarily low income levels or even negative income levels; but the dairy industry is one of the great exceptions.

title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker; I will oblige and refer my remarksWednesday, 8 May 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE MC693 It varies a little from state to state, but the average farm operating surplus on Australia's dairy farms will be in the order of $60,000 to $65,000 this year, and that is a tremendous result. Of course, players are always a little like that other great industry that is doing reasonably well at the moment: the sugar industry. When you talk to them and say, 'Isn't it marvellous to see your industry doing well?' they all say, 'Ah, yes! But, before you think of making any government changes that might impact on us, it won't be so good next year. Remember that these things are cyclical.' And that is probably a timely warning. I would remind him that, while we have dealt with wool and now sugar, the dairy industry is the subject of the bill. recognising the challenge set by this outstanding industry. We are reinforcing its capacity to continue to set a scorching pace and an example that the rest of us need to be following. Nonetheless, with all due deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will refer to the matter in hand. One of the interesting things is recognising the potential for the industry in Australia and the ideal nature of our geographic position in relation to Asia. We are now seeing significant investment by companies such as Nestle-again in the Goulburn Valley in particular-and, interestingly enough, by the Japanese, with Snow brand, for example, producing skim milk powder and baby milk formula. That constitutes a recognition by the Japanese that, as the old protectionist policies are wound back in their homelands, competitive suppliers like Australia will have an ever greater potential for the future and that they ought to be in here on the ground floor. I have been to the Goulburn Valley a few times now and I have seen what is happening there. It is very exciting and it is reflected in many, many other areas of Australia, even in north-western New South Wales, where there are now a significant number of dairy operators who are buying up country inland because they can extract a return there that other farmers cannot from their activities. I noticed the previous speaker touched on the United States and their trading practices. We note, and I have had the good fortune to put this to the Americans in the last couple of days, that their farm bill does in fact make some very significant and worthwhile reforms. For the first time since the program was set up by Roosevelt in the 1930s, the income support programs will be decoupled from production. That is very welcome, but there are a couple of things we do not welcome. One is that both EEP and DIEP, the dairy industry export program, remain. They actually have not used EEP for grains since July of last year because grain prices are high and they have not needed them. But, as the previous speaker pointed out, they are quite aggressively, within the very clear boundaries of what they are allowed to do under WTO-as opposed to perhaps the spirit of WTO-using DIEP to the outer limits. It appears that that is the objective. We are seeking assurances from the Americans that they will respect the undertakings that they have given us not to harm Australia, as a non-subsidising nation and one that is not supposedly in their sights in terms of their engagement with the Europeans, and that they will seek to protect our interests. We sincerely hope that they will be able to, in a comprehensive and integrated way, honour those broad commitments. We do not mind competing with the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker
theText: Before the minister gets on to lambs and pork and other things,
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: Yes, but these are all important points because they have to do withMC 694 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 8 May 1996 world's best-we think we can cream them in a lot of ways-but we do not want to do that in an environment where people have unfairly funded-taxpayer funded-advantages. That brings me to a couple of closing remarks about the New Zealanders, who are also very aggressive, very powerful competitors and who have a very major dairy export industry-I think they export over 90 per cent of their dairy product. They are a major player on the world stage in this regard. They have progressed further and faster down the reform road than we have. This does raise some issues for us. I would put those in a couple of categories. One is that we would require of the New Zealanders that they do everything to honour the gentleman's agreement that we have with them in terms of access to our markets because we do not impose the levy that we are talking about here in this legislation-in terms of minor amendments to the legislation-on them when they sell their products on our shelves. That, of course, does constitute something of an advantage for them. They have given us an undertaking that they will not take advantage of that situation and we would be very keen to see that gentlemen's agreement upheld. Again, I can confirm to you that I have taken that issue up personally with the New Zealanders. They have responded in good faith, in an appropriate way. But, to build on that, it does indicate the need for us to get on with urgent reforms-and there are many of them on the government's agenda which are important to the dairy industry. I do not intend to talk at length now about appropriate structures, and so forth, for the dairy industry. Broadly speaking, a lot of that work has been done. The right economic environment is obviously important, fixing the big black hole so that we can ensure that·interest rates are as globally competitive, if you like, as they can be. That is what you need when you are in an export industry in this country-interest rates that allow you to be globally competitive. We do not have them, largely because of past economic policy. Those sorts of things do need to be addressed. There is one area I want to touch on finally. One of our great competitive advantages in Asia springs from our clean, green image. It is no secret that, whilst our product is clean and green, there are challenges before us in primary industry in this country if we are to maintain that clean and green image and to continue to produce sustainably. Again, many of those challenges are evident in southern New South Wales and northern Victoria as we attempt to battle such issues as salinity. The coalition government has a very comprehensive landcare package which incorporates such things as tax rebates and credits for farmers. They are an ideal mechanism both to facilitate the fanner-who, in the end, spends the bulk of the money and does the work on landcare initiatives, be they salinity or whatever, to meet sustainable agricultural objectivesand to let the community, which has a great vested interest in sustainable production, make an investment as well. The community gets a great return from that investment, not just in terms of more jobs and more taxes paid to Treasury, but also in terms of being able to secure the resource base for future generations. The tax credit rebate approach is an ideal part of that armoury. It is also part and parcel of our environment package and I again issue the challenge: if you want what is undoubtedly the best environment-landcare-environmentally sustainable production package ever put before the Australian people in this country, it needs to be recognised that the approach we have put up, with a $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust to be funded out of the partial privatisation of Telstra, is sound policy that cannot be legitimately resisted by anybody who has a proper, deep Wednesday, 8 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC695 and sincere commitment to these issues of sound environmental management and sustainable agricultural production. Thank you for your indulgence. I believe the issues that I have touched on are important. But, in particular, I again want to thank all who have participated in the debate very sincerely indeed, both for their contribution and for their agreement to the objectives sought here today. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported without amendment. Second Reading Consideration resumed. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Main Committee adjourned at 12.26 p.m.
